newsitem.title: BULGARIA: SOFIA CONFERENCE SEEKS TO REVIVE OLD ROMAN ROUTES.
newsitem.headline: SOFIA CONFERENCE SEEKS TO REVIVE OLD ROMAN ROUTES.

text.p: Transport ministers from the Central European Initiative and the Black Sea Economic Cooperation meeting in Sofia proposed reviving Roman routes across Europe to integrate them with the rest of Europe.

Ministers and representatives from 22 countries at a two-day conference, which ended on Friday, discussed how to link their transport infrastructure to existing trans-European routes and attract investment for development.

"Central and eastern Europe aim to integrate their transport infrastructure in the region firstly because such integration will be a springboard towards integrating with the European infrastructure," said a senior Bulgarian official.
Among dozens of proposals, Yugoslavia and Croatia proposed reviving the Via Militanta which passed from Germany via Budapest and Sofia to Constantinople.
Croatia has suggested an Adriatic corridor via Albania to western Greece, which is also a very ancient route, officials said.

Ten countries have signed a memorandum for the establishment of a trans-regional centre in Sofia to coordinate efforts to attract investment and promote countries' economic cooperation and their integration with the European Union.
"We expect other countries to sign the memorandum after we clarify the centre's structure and finances," Bulgaria's transport minister Stamen Stamenov said.
He said the 10 countries were Romania, Macedonia, Albania, Russia, Ukraine, Georgia, Moldova, Azerbaijan, Belarus and Bulgaria.
Bulgaria and Croatia signed two intergovernment agreements on road transportation of people and freight and air transport.
Bulgaria and Romania signed a protocol to renew negotiations by the year-end over building a new Danube river bridge following years of disagreement over its location.
